column2: He looked around for the "torture bottle," but it was not in sight.
column3: He looked around for the "torture bottle," but it was not in sight.

column2: Who is this? he asked, and lifted the cloth from the man's face.
column3: Who is this? he asked, and lifted the cloth from the man's face.

column2: It was Milburgh.
column3: It was Milburgh.

column2: CHAPTER XXXIII
column3: CHAPTER thirty three

column2: LING CHU--TORTURER
column3: LING CHU-TORTURER

column2: Much had happened to Mr. Milburgh between the time of his discovery lying bound and helpless and showing evidence that he had been in the hands of a Chinese torturer and the moment he left Sam Stay.
column3: Much had happened to mr Milburgh between the time of his discovery lying bound and helpless and showing evidence that he had been in the hands of a Chinese torturer and the moment he left Sam Stay.

column2: He had read of the murder, and had been shocked, and, in his way, grieved.
column3: He had read of the murder, and had been shocked, and, in his way, grieved.

column2: It was not to save Odette Rider that he sent his note to Scotland Yard, but rather to avenge himself upon the man who had killed the only woman in the world who had touched his warped nature.
column3: It was not to save Odette Rider that he sent his note to Scotland Yard, but rather to avenge himself upon the man who had killed the only woman in the world who had touched his warped nature.

column2: Nor had he any intention of committing suicide.
column3: Nor had he any intention of committing suicide.

column2: He had the passports which he had secured a year before in readiness for such a step (he had kept that clerical uniform of his by him all that time) and was ready at a moment's notice to leave the country.
column3: He had the passports which he had secured a year before in readiness for such a step (he had kept that clerical uniform of his by him all that time) and was ready at a moment's notice to leave the country.

column2: His tickets were in his pocket, and when he despatched the district messenger to Scotland Yard he was on his way to Waterloo station to catch the Havre boat train.
column3: His tickets were in his pocket, and when he despatched the district messenger to Scotland Yard he was on his way to Waterloo station to catch the Havre boat train.

column2: The police, he knew, would be watching the station, but he had no fear that they would discover beneath the benign exterior of a country clergyman, the wanted manager of Lyne's Store, even supposing that there was a warrant out for his arrest.
column3: The police, he knew, would be watching the station, but he had no fear that they would discover beneath the benign exterior of a country clergyman, the wanted manager of Lyne's Store, even supposing that there was a warrant out for his arrest.

column2: He was standing at a bookstall, purchasing literature to while away the hours of the journey, when he felt a hand laid on his arm and experienced a curious sinking sensation.
column3: He was standing at a bookstall, purchasing literature to while away the hours of the journey, when he felt a hand laid on his arm and experienced a curious sinking sensation.

column2: He turned to look into a brown mask of a face he had seen before.
column3: He turned to look into a brown mask of a face he had seen before.

column2: Well, my man, he asked with a smile, "what can I do for you?"
column3: Well, my man, he asked with a smile, "what can I do for you?"

column2: He had asked the question in identical terms of Sam Stay--his brain told him that much, mechanically.
column3: He had asked the question in identical terms of Sam Stay-his brain told him that much, mechanically.

column2: You will come with me, Mr. Milburgh, said Ling Chu.
column3: You will come with me, mr Milburgh, said Ling Chu.

column2: It will be better for you if you do not make any trouble.
column3: It will be better for you if you do not make any trouble.

column2: You are making a mistake.
column3: You are making a mistake.

column2: If I am making a mistake, said Ling Chu calmly, "you have only to tell that policeman that I have mistaken you for Milburgh, who is wanted by the police on a charge of murder, and I shall get into very serious trouble."
column3: If I am making a mistake, said Ling Chu calmly, "you have only to tell that policeman that I have mistaken you for Milburgh, who is wanted by the police on a charge of murder, and I shall get into very serious trouble."

column2: Milburgh's lips were quivering with fear and his face was a pasty grey.
column3: Milburgh's lips were quivering with fear and his face was a pasty grey.

column2: I will come, he said.
column3: I will come, he said.

column2: Ling Chu walked by his side, and they passed out of Waterloo station.
column3: Ling Chu walked by his side, and they passed out of Waterloo station.

column2: The journey to Bond Street remained in Milburgh's memory like a horrible dream.
column3: The journey to Bond Street remained in Milburgh's memory like a horrible dream.

column2: He was not used to travelling on omnibuses, being something of a sybarite who spared nothing to ensure his own comfort.
column3: He was not used to travelling on omnibuses, being something of a sybarite who spared nothing to ensure his own comfort.

column2: Ling Chu on the contrary had a penchant for buses and seemed to enjoy them.
column3: Ling Chu on the contrary had a penchant for buses and seemed to enjoy them.

column2: No word was spoken until they reached the sitting-room of Tarling's flat. Milburgh expected to see the detective.
column3: No word was spoken until they reached the sitting room of Tarling's flat. Milburgh expected to see the detective.

column2: He had already arrived at the conclusion that Ling Chu was but a messenger who had been sent by the man from Shanghai to bring him to his presence.
column3: He had already arrived at the conclusion that Ling Chu was but a messenger who had been sent by the man from Shanghai to bring him to his presence.

column2: But there was no sign of Tarling.
column3: But there was no sign of Tarling.

column2: Now, my friend, what do you want? he asked.
column3: Now, my friend, what do you want? he asked.

column2: It is true I am Mr. Milburgh, but when you say that I have committed murder you are telling a wicked lie.
column3: It is true I am mr Milburgh, but when you say that I have committed murder you are telling a wicked lie.

column2: He had gained some courage, because he had expected in the first place to be taken immediately to Scotland Yard and placed in custody.
column3: He had gained some courage, because he had expected in the first place to be taken immediately to Scotland Yard and placed in custody.

column2: The fact that Tarling's flat lay at the end of the journey seemed to suggest that the situation was not as desperate as he had imagined.
column3: The fact that Tarling's flat lay at the end of the journey seemed to suggest that the situation was not as desperate as he had imagined.

column2: Ling Chu, turning suddenly upon Milburgh, gripped him by the wrist, half-turning as he did so.
column3: Ling Chu, turning suddenly upon Milburgh, gripped him by the wrist, half turning as he did so.

column2: Before Milburgh knew what was happening, he was lying on the floor, face downwards, with Ling Chu's knee in the small of his back.
column3: Before Milburgh knew what was happening, he was lying on the floor, face downwards, with Ling Chu's knee in the small of his back.

column2: He felt something like a wire loop slipped about his wrists, and suffered an excruciating pain as the Chinaman tightened the connecting link of the native handcuff.
column3: He felt something like a wire loop slipped about his wrists, and suffered an excruciating pain as the Chinaman tightened the connecting link of the native handcuff.

column2: Get up, said Ling Chu sternly, and, exerting a surprising strength, lifted the man to his feet.
column3: Get up, said Ling Chu sternly, and, exerting a surprising strength, lifted the man to his feet.

column2: What are you going to do? said Milburgh, his teeth chattering with fear.
column3: What are you going to do? said Milburgh, his teeth chattering with fear.

column2: There was no answer.
column3: There was no answer.

column2: Ling Chu gripped the man by one hand and opening the door with the other, pushed him into a room which was barely furnished. Against the wall there was an iron bed, and on to this the man was pushed, collapsing in a heap.
column3: Ling Chu gripped the man by one hand and opening the door with the other, pushed him into a room which was barely furnished. Against the wall there was an iron bed, and on to this the man was pushed, collapsing in a heap.

column2: The Chinese thief-catcher went about his work in a scientific fashion. First he fastened and threaded a length of silk rope through one of the rails of the bed and into the slack of this he lifted Milburgh's head, so that he could not struggle except at the risk of being strangled.
column3: The Chinese thief catcher went about his work in a scientific fashion. First he fastened and threaded a length of silk rope through one of the rails of the bed and into the slack of this he lifted Milburgh's head, so that he could not struggle except at the risk of being strangled.

column2: Ling Chu turned him over, unfastened the handcuffs, and methodically bound first one wrist and then the other to the side of the bed.
column3: Ling Chu turned him over, unfastened the handcuffs, and methodically bound first one wrist and then the other to the side of the bed.

column2: What are you going to do? repeated Milburgh, but the Chinaman made no reply.
column3: What are you going to do? repeated Milburgh, but the Chinaman made no reply.

column2: He produced from a belt beneath his blouse a wicked-looking knife, and the manager opened his mouth to shout.
column3: He produced from a belt beneath his blouse a wicked looking knife, and the manager opened his mouth to shout.

column2: He was beside himself with terror, but any cause for fear had yet to come.
column3: He was beside himself with terror, but any cause for fear had yet to come.

column2: The Chinaman stopped the cry by dropping a pillow on the man's face, and began deliberately to cut the clothing on the upper part of his body.
column3: The Chinaman stopped the cry by dropping a pillow on the man's face, and began deliberately to cut the clothing on the upper part of his body.

column2: If you cry out, he said calmly, "the people will think it is I who am singing!
column3: If you cry out, he said calmly, "the people will think it is I who am singing!

column2: Chinamen have no music in their voices, and sometimes when I have sung my native songs, people have come up to discover who was suffering."
column3: Chinamen have no music in their voices, and sometimes when I have sung my native songs, people have come up to discover who was suffering."

column2: You are acting illegally, breathed Milburgh, in a last attempt to save the situation.
column3: You are acting illegally, breathed Milburgh, in a last attempt to save the situation.

column2: For your crime you will suffer imprisonment
column3: For your crime you will suffer imprisonment

column2: I shall be fortunate, said Ling Chu; "for prison is life.
column3: I shall be fortunate, said Ling Chu; "for prison is life.

column2: But you will hang at the end of a long rope."
column3: But you will hang at the end of a long rope."

column2: He had lifted the pillow from Milburgh's face, and now that pallid man was following every movement of the Chinaman with a fearful eye. Presently Milburgh was stripped to the waist, and Ling Chu regarded his handiwork complacently.
column3: He had lifted the pillow from Milburgh's face, and now that pallid man was following every movement of the Chinaman with a fearful eye. Presently Milburgh was stripped to the waist, and Ling Chu regarded his handiwork complacently.

column2: He went to a cupboard in the wall, and took out a small brown bottle, which he placed on a table by the side of the bed.
column3: He went to a cupboard in the wall, and took out a small brown bottle, which he placed on a table by the side of the bed.

column2: Then he himself sat upon the edge of the bed and spoke.
column3: Then he himself sat upon the edge of the bed and spoke.

column2: His English was almost perfect, though now and again he hesitated in the choice of a word, and there were moments when he was a little stilted in his speech, and more than a little pedantic.
column3: His English was almost perfect, though now and again he hesitated in the choice of a word, and there were moments when he was a little stilted in his speech, and more than a little pedantic.

column2: He spoke slowly and with great deliberation.
column3: He spoke slowly and with great deliberation.

column2: You do not know the Chinese people?	You do not know the Chinese people?
column3: true

column2: You have not been or lived in China? When I say lived I do not mean staying for a week at a good hotel in one of the coast towns.
column3: You have not been or lived in China? When I say lived I do not mean staying for a week at a good hotel in one of the coast towns.

column2: Your Mr. Lyne lived in China in that way.
column3: Your mr Lyne lived in China in that way.

column2: It was not a successful residence."
column3: It was not a successful residence."

column2: I know nothing about Mr. Lyne, interrupted Milburgh, sensing that Ling Chu in some way associated him with Thornton Lyne's misadventures.
column3: I know nothing about mr Lyne, interrupted Milburgh, sensing that Ling Chu in some way associated him with Thornton Lyne's misadventures.

column2: Good! said Ling Chu, tapping the flat blade of his knife upon his palm. "If you had lived in China--in the real China--you might have a dim idea of our people and their characteristics.
column3: Good! said Ling Chu, tapping the flat blade of his knife upon his palm. "If you had lived in China-in the real China-you might have a dim idea of our people and their characteristics.

column2: It is said that the Chinaman does not fear death or pain, which is a slight exaggeration, because I have known criminals who feared both."
column3: It is said that the Chinaman does not fear death or pain, which is a slight exaggeration, because I have known criminals who feared both."

column2: His thin lips curved for a second in the ghost of a smile, as though at some amusing recollection.
column3: His thin lips curved for a second in the ghost of a smile, as though at some amusing recollection.

column2: Then he grew serious again.
column3: Then he grew serious again.

column2: From the Western standpoint we are a primitive people.	From the Western standpoint we are a primitive people.
column3: true

column2: From our own point of view we are rigidly honourable.
column3: From our own point of view we are rigidly honourable.

column2: Also--and this I would emphasise." He did, in fact, emphasise his words to the terror of Mr. Milburgh, with the point of his knife upon the other's broad chest, though so lightly was the knife held that Milburgh felt nothing but the slightest tingle.
column3: Also-and this I would emphasise." He did, in fact, emphasise his words to the terror of mr Milburgh, with the point of his knife upon the other's broad chest, though so lightly was the knife held that Milburgh felt nothing but the slightest tingle.

column2: We do not set the same value upon the rights of the individual as do you people in the West.	We do not set the same value upon the rights of the individual as do you people in the West.
column3: true

column2: For example," he explained carefully, "we are not tender with our prisoners, if we think that by applying a little pressure to them we can assist the process of justice."
column3: For example," he explained carefully, "we are not tender with our prisoners, if we think that by applying a little pressure to them we can assist the process of justice."

column2: What do you mean? asked Milburgh, a grisly thought dawning upon his mind.
column3: What do you mean? asked Milburgh, a grisly thought dawning upon his mind.

column2: In Britain--and in America too, I understand--though the Americans are much more enlightened on this subject--when you arrest a member of a gang you are content with cross-examining him and giving him full scope for the exercise of his inventive power.	In Britain-and in America too, I understand-though the Americans are much more enlightened on this subject-when you arrest a member of a gang you are content with cross examining him and giving him full scope for the exercise of his inventive power.

column2: You ask him questions and go on asking and asking, and you do not know whether he is lying or telling the truth."
column3: You ask him questions and go on asking and asking, and you do not know whether he is lying or telling the truth."

column2: Mr. Milburgh began to breathe heavily.

column2: Has that idea sunk into your mind? asked Ling Chu.
column3: Has that idea sunk into your mind? asked Ling Chu.

column2: I don't know what you mean, said Mr. Milburgh in a quavering voice. "All I know is that you are committing a most----"
column3: I don't know what you mean, said mr Milburgh in a quavering voice. "All I know is that you are committing a most----"

column2: Ling Chu stopped him with a gesture.
column3: Ling Chu stopped him with a gesture.

column2: I am perfectly well aware of what I am doing, he said.
column3: I am perfectly well aware of what I am doing, he said.

column2: Now listen to me.	Now listen to me.
column3: true

column2: A week or so ago, Mr. Thornton Lyne, your employer, was found dead in Hyde Park.
column3: A week or so ago, mr Thornton Lyne, your employer, was found dead in Hyde Park.

column2: He was dressed in his shirt and trousers, and about his body, in an endeavour to stanch the wound, somebody had wrapped a silk night-dress.
column3: He was dressed in his shirt and trousers, and about his body, in an endeavour to stanch the wound, somebody had wrapped a silk night dress.

column2: He was killed in the flat of a small lady, whose name I cannot pronounce, but you will know her."
column3: He was killed in the flat of a small lady, whose name I cannot pronounce, but you will know her."

column2: Milburgh's eyes never left the Chinaman's, and he nodded.
column3: Milburgh's eyes never left the Chinaman's, and he nodded.

column2: He was killed by you, said Ling Chu slowly, "because he had discovered that you had been robbing him, and you were in fear that he would hand you over to the police."
column3: He was killed by you, said Ling Chu slowly, "because he had discovered that you had been robbing him, and you were in fear that he would hand you over to the police."

column2: That's a lie, roared Milburgh.
column3: That's a lie, roared Milburgh.

column2: It's a lie--I tell you it's a lie!
column3: It's a lie-I tell you it's a lie!

column2: I shall discover whether it is a lie in a few moments, said Ling Chu.
column3: I shall discover whether it is a lie in a few moments, said Ling Chu.

column2: He put his hand inside his blouse and Milburgh watched him fascinated, but he produced nothing more deadly than a silver cigarette-case, which he opened.
column3: He put his hand inside his blouse and Milburgh watched him fascinated, but he produced nothing more deadly than a silver cigarette case, which he opened.

column2: He selected a cigarette and lit it, and for a few minutes puffed in silence, his thoughtful eyes fixed upon Milburgh.
column3: He selected a cigarette and lit it, and for a few minutes puffed in silence, his thoughtful eyes fixed upon Milburgh.

column2: Then he rose and went to the cupboard and took out a larger bottle and placed it beside the other.
column3: Then he rose and went to the cupboard and took out a larger bottle and placed it beside the other.

column2: Ling Chu pulled again at his cigarette and then threw it into the grate.
column3: Ling Chu pulled again at his cigarette and then threw it into the grate.

column2: It is in the interests of all parties, he said in his slow, halting way, "that the truth should be known, both for the sake of my honourable master, Lieh Jen, the Hunter, and his honourable Little Lady."
column3: It is in the interests of all parties, he said in his slow, halting way, "that the truth should be known, both for the sake of my honourable master, Lieh Jen, the Hunter, and his honourable Little Lady."

column2: He took up his knife and bent over the terror-stricken man.
column3: He took up his knife and bent over the terror stricken man.

column2: For God's sake don't, don't, half screamed, half sobbed Milburgh.
column3: For God's sake don't, don't, half screamed, half sobbed Milburgh.

column2: This will not hurt you, said Ling Chu, and drew four straight lines across the other's breast.

column3: The keen razor edge seemed scarcely to touch the flesh, yet where the knife had passed was a thin red mark like a scratch.

column2: In this, he said, "is a vegetable extract.

column2: It is what you would call capsicum, but it is not quite like your pepper because it is distilled from a native root.
column3: It is what you would call capsicum, but it is not quite like your pepper because it is distilled from a native root.

column2: In this bottle," he picked up the larger, "is a Chinese oil which immediately relieves the pain which capsicum causes."
column3: In this bottle," he picked up the larger, "is a Chinese oil which immediately relieves the pain which capsicum causes."

column2: What are you going to do? asked Milburgh, struggling.
column3: What are you going to do? asked Milburgh, struggling.

column2: You dog!	You dog!
column3: true

column2: You fiend!"
column3: You fiend!"

column2: With a little brush I will paint capsicum on these places. He touched Milburgh's chest with his long white ringers.
column3: With a little brush I will paint capsicum on these places. He touched Milburgh's chest with his long white ringers.

column2: Little by little, millimetre by millimetre my brush will move, and you will experience such pain as you have never experienced before.	Little by little, millimetre by millimetre my brush will move, and you will experience such pain as you have never experienced before.

column2: It is pain which will rack you from head to foot, and will remain with you all your life in memory. Sometimes," he said philosophically, "it drives me mad, but I do not think it will drive you mad."
column3: It is pain which will rack you from head to foot, and will remain with you all your life in memory. Sometimes," he said philosophically, "it drives me mad, but I do not think it will drive you mad."

column2: He took out the cork and dipped a little camel-hair brush in the mixture, withdrawing it moist with fluid.
column3: He took out the cork and dipped a little camel hair brush in the mixture, withdrawing it moist with fluid.

column2: He was watching Milburgh all the time, and when the stout man opened his mouth to yell he thrust a silk handkerchief, which he drew with lightning speed from his pocket, into the open mouth.
column3: He was watching Milburgh all the time, and when the stout man opened his mouth to yell he thrust a silk handkerchief, which he drew with lightning speed from his pocket, into the open mouth.

column2: Wait, wait! gasped the muffled voice of Milburgh.
column3: Wait, wait! gasped the muffled voice of Milburgh.

column2: I have something to tell you--something that your master should know.
column3: I have something to tell you-something that your master should know.

column2: That is very good, said Ling Chu coolly, and pulled out the handkerchief.
column3: That is very good, said Ling Chu coolly, and pulled out the handkerchief.

column2: You shall tell me the truth.
column3: You shall tell me the truth.

column2: What truth can I tell you? asked the man, sweating with fear.
column3: What truth can I tell you? asked the man, sweating with fear.

column2: Great beads of sweat were lying on his face.
column3: Great beads of sweat were lying on his face.

column2: You shall confess the truth that you killed Thornton Lyne, said Ling Chu.
column3: You shall confess the truth that you killed Thornton Lyne, said Ling Chu.

column2: That is the only truth I want to hear.

column2: Do you know what has happened to Miss Rider?
column3: Do you know what has happened to Miss Rider?

column3: The Chinaman checked his movement.

column2: To Miss Rider? he said quickly. (He pronounced the word "Lider.")
column3: To Miss Rider? he said quickly. (He pronounced the word "Lider.")

column2: Brokenly, gaspingly, breathlessly, Milburgh told the story of his meeting with Sam Stay.
column3: Brokenly, gaspingly, breathlessly, Milburgh told the story of his meeting with Sam Stay.

column2: In his distress and mental anguish he reproduced faithfully not only every word, but every intonation, and the Chinaman listened with half-closed eyes.
column3: In his distress and mental anguish he reproduced faithfully not only every word, but every intonation, and the Chinaman listened with half closed eyes.

column2: Then, when Milburgh had finished, he put down his bottle and thrust in the cork.

column2: My master would wish that the little woman should escape danger, he said.
column3: My master would wish that the little woman should escape danger, he said.

column2: To-night he does not return, so I must go myself to the hospital--you can wait.

column2: You can wait, he said with a sinister smile.

column2: I will go first to the hospital and afterwards, if all is well, I will return for you.

column2: He took a clean white towel from the dressing-table and laid it over his victim's face.
column3: He took a clean white towel from the dressing table and laid it over his victim's face.
